newsitem.title: UK: Coffee turns hot commodity in UK crime wave.
newsitem.headline: Coffee turns hot commodity in UK crime wave.

text.p: Soaring world prices for coffee have turned the jar of instant into a prime target among British shoplifters.
Police and lawyers said coffee theft was rampant in some inner cities so that jars were being placed out of reach or stocked discreetly by supermarkets.

"People who are in multiple debts are stealing coffee because it is relatively easy to sell or use as repayment to money lenders in lieu of cash," said Harry Fletcher, assistant general secretary of the National Association of Probation Officers.
He said there had been a marked increase in coffee theft in London and several other big cities.
Tom Ward, a lawyer in Scotland who has represented several people accused of stealing coffee, said a big jar costing seven sterling or about $11.50 and could be re-sold at half the price.
Detective Sergeant Alistair Morris, a police officer in Greenock, Scotland, said: "It is a problem elsewhere I would imagine."
The spate of coffee theft followed an increase in retail prices after world futures for the beans doubled since January.

Supply disruptions from Colombia and concerns over a lower crop in Brazil, the biggest producer, with a rush of buying by roasters (processors) who were running low of stocks, fuelled the rally that attracted eager speculative interest.
Some of the cost has been passed on to consumers. Nestle, the leading British instant coffee maker, has put up its retail prices twice this year.
